BiblioData.Title: NANOCRYSTAL SOLAR CELLS PROCESSED FROM SOLUTION

Applicant.Name: UNIV CALIFORNIA [US]
THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA

BiblioData.Abstract: A photovoltaic device having a first electrode layer, a high resistivity transparent film disposed on the first electrode, a second electrode layer, and an inorganic photoactive layer disposed between the first and second electrode layers, wherein the inorganic photoactive layer is disposed in at least partial electrical contact with the high resistivity transparent film, and in at least partial electrical contact with the second electrode. The photoactive layer has a first inorganic material and a second inorganic material different from the first inorganic material, wherein the first and second inorganic materials exhibit a type II band offset energy profile, and wherein the photoactive layer has a first population of nanostructures of a first inorganic material and a second population of nanostructures of a second inorganic material.

Claims.P: WHAT IS CLAIMED IS:

1. A photovoltaic device, comprising: a first electrode layer; a high resistivity transparent film disposed on the first electrode; a second electrode layer; and an inorganic photoactive layer disposed between the first and second electrode layers, wherein the inorganic photoactive layer is disposed in at least partial electrical contact with the high resistivity transparent film, and in at least partial electrical contact with the second electrode, and wherein the photoactive layer comprises a first inorganic material and a second inorganic material different from the first inorganic material, wherein the first and second inorganic materials exhibit a type II band offset energy profile, and wherein the photoactive layer comprises a first population of nanostructures of a first inorganic material and a second population of nanostructures of a second inorganic material. 2. The device of claim 1 wherein the first population of nanostructures comprises nanorods.
3. The device of claim 1 wherein the second population of nanostructures comprises nanorods.
4. The photovoltaic device of claim 1, wherein at least a portion of the nanostructures comprises a material selected from the group consisting of Group H-VI, Group III-V, and Group
1-V semiconductors and alloys thereof.

5. The photovoltaic device of claim 1, wherein the population of nanostructures comprises nanorods, comprising a material selected from the group consisting of CdSe, CdTe5 InP, InAs, CdS, ZnS, ZnSc, ZnTc, HgTc, GaN, GaP, GaAs, GaSb, InSb, Si, Gc, AlAs, AlSb, PbSe, PbS, PbTe, and combinations thereof .
6. The photovoltaic device of claim 1, wherein the population of nanorods comprises a core of first inorganic material and a shell of a second inorganic material.

7. The photovoltaic device of claim 6, wherein the core comprises CdSe and the shell comprises CdTe. 8. The photovoltaic device of claim 6, wherein the core comprises InP and the shell comprises GaAs.
9. The photovoltaic device of claim 1, wherein at least one of the first and second electrodes comprises a transparent conductive layer.
10. The photovoltaic device of claim 1, wherein at least one of the first and second electrodes comprises a reflective metal.

11. The photovoltaic device of claim 11, wherein the reflective metal comprises aluminum, calcium, nickel, or copper. 12. The photovoltaic device of claim 1 wherein the high resistivity transparent film comprises aluminum oxide.
13. The photovoltaic device of claim 12 wherein the aluminum oxide is deposited hy an atomic layer deposition process.
14. The photovoltaic device of claim 1 wherein the high resistivity transparent film is dimensioned to result in a maximum power output from the photovoltaic device. Is this defined?
15. The photovoltaic device of claim 1 wherein the inorganic photoactive layer is a sintered layer.
16. The photovoltaic device of claim 15 wherein the sintered layer is sintered to undergo crystal grain growth.
17. The photovoltaic device of claim 15 wherein the sintered layer is sintered to undergo a recrystallization and a crystal grain growth.

18. The photovoltaic device of claim 15 wherein the sintered layer is formed by exposing the inorganic photoactive layer to cadmium chloride and then heating the cadmium chloride- exposed layer in air at an elevated temperature.
19. The photovoltaic device of claim 18 wherein the heating is conducted at a temperature of approximately 400C. for approximately fifteen minutes.

20. The photovoltaic device of claim 1 being air-stable in the absence of an encapsulating layer. 21. A method of forming a nanocrystal film, comprising: a. providing a concentrated solution containing nanocrystals; b. spin-casting the solution onto a substrate to form a green film; c. spin-casting a saturated solution OfCdCl2 in methanol onto the green film; d. heating the green film to approximately 400C hi oxygen; and e. holding the film and substrate at approximately 10<"> torr.
22. The method of claim 21 wherein the concentrated solution contains nanocrystals containing at least two different materials.

23. A method of forming a bi-layer nanocrystal film, comprising: a. providing a first concentrated solution containing nanocrystals of a first material type; b. spin-casting the first solution onto a substrate to form a single-layer green film; c. providing a second concentrated solution containing nanocrystals of a second material type; d. spin-casting the second solution onto a substrate to form a double-layer green film; e. spin-casting a saturated solution of CdC12 in methanol onto the double-layer green film; f. heating the double-layer green film to approximately 400C in oxygen; and g. holding the film and substrate at approximately 10<"6>torr.
